document_title: Bladder stones: Causes, signs, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
If not treated promptly and properly, the patient may face complications such as:
Cystitis: When the stones are small, the patient may not see any problems. Bladder stones that grow larger than 2cm often have symptoms of bladder irritation such as frequent urination, painful urination, interrupted urination or hematuria. If there is no early treatment, bladder inflammation can become chronic, leading to bladder atrophy, bladder fistula, and bladder cancer.; Nephritis: due to upstream bacterial infection from the bladder, can impair kidney function. This complication can greatly affect health and is very difficult to treat.; Lower abdominal pain: Patients often feel sharp pain in the lower abdomen due to bladder irritation and stones stuck in the bladder neck. Lower abdominal pain can spread to the perineum or the tip of the external genitals, causing discomfort for the patient.; Bladder fistula: Large bladder stones can cause bladder fistula, perineal or vaginal fistula in women. Urine leaks continuously through the fistula, causing infection in the vaginal or anal area. Patients will experience many inconveniences in daily activities.
